newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina may use YPF stake as loan collateral.
newsitem.headline: Argentina may use YPF stake as loan collateral.

text.p: Argentine Economy Minister Roque Fernandez is studying using the government's remaining stake in YPF SA as collateral for a loan of up to $1.0 billion, his chief aide said Monday.
"The Economy Minister has acknowledged this and is studying it," aide Carlos Rodriguez told reporters.

He said the loan from international banks could be about $1.0 billion "but it depends...on whether we sell all or part" of the government's 20 percent stake in the oil company, which was privatized in 1993.

Fernndez revealed last week that Argentina would have to raise $1.0 billion from privatizations this year to bridge the projected $6.6 billion budget gap. Most of that revenue would come from the sale of the YPF stake, he said.

He had hoped for $1.2 billion of budget-boosting funds from a fiscal austerity package sent to Congress last week, but says parliamentary delays are now likely to reduce the impact to $600 million. Fernndez also spoke last week of seeking $4.0 billion of fresh loans this year.
An International Monetary Fund mission is currently in town studying Fernndez's efforts to bridget the deficit. The IMF had agreed to a $2.5 billion deficit for the whole year.

Rodrguez, who had told Ambito Financiero newspaper in an interview Monday that the IMF mission would last two or three weeks, told reporters the aim was to renegotiate terms of a $1.05 billion, 21-month standby IMF loan for Argentina in April "for which we need a waiver for the second quarter and to set more realistic goals."
Fernndez said Friday after meeting the IMF mission that he foresaw "no problems in getting a waiver" and had the IMF's support for his fiscal austerity programme.
Once such a waiver is secured, Rodrguez said, the government might be interested in seeking an Extended Fund Facility, such as the one Argentina secured in March 1992.
"But it is not healthy to start an Extended Fund Facility on the base of a failed standby," said Rodrguez.

The official said he expects Roque Fernndez to launch a roadshow in foreign debt markets once it becomes clear what Argentina's financing needs are in the light of the IMF accord and Congress' treatment of his austerity package.
